awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Spoof-Resistant Smartphone Authentication using Cooperating Wearables
awd_abstract_narration:
This research is developing methods that leverage a multitude of sensors embedded in hand-held and wearable devices (e.g., smart watches, smart glasses and brain-computer interfaces) for strong user authentication to smart phones. The current point-of-entry solutions, largely based on weak static credentials, such as passwords or PINs for authentication to smart phones are not sufficient because once such credentials are compromised (which is very likely given the many vulnerabilities of passwords), the attacker may gain unfettered access to the smart phone. In this light, it becomes necessary to constantly protect the smart phone even after the attacker has already bypassed the point-of-entry authentication functionality. This research aims to address this problem by developing methods through which cues extracted from one or more wearable devices will be used in conjunction with cues extracted from the phone itself to continuously and unobtrusively verify the authenticity of the user. In addition to advancing knowledge on how wearable devices can help improve smart phone security, the research will have a number of other broader impacts including, mentoring of undergraduate students, outreach to high school and K-12 students and minority populations, and technology transfer by collaborating with manufacturers and industrial consortia.

The principal argument underlying this research is that, given the rise of sensor-equipped and wearable computing, a wide array of identifying cues might be available in many circumstances and can therefore be leveraged to build user-friendly and spoof-resistant smart phone authentication systems. The overarching approach is to not only capture explicit user interactions (based on touch screen sensors) when applicable, but also capture implicit user interactions based on a conglomeration of a multitude of smart phone on-board sensors as well as wearable device sensors. The on-board sensors are inertial (motion and orientation) sensors residing on the smart phone itself and measure users' implicit interactions with the phone, specifically, phone movements, tilts and orientations. The wearable sensors, in contrast, are inertial and neuro-physiological sensors residing on "collaborating" wearable devices, "paired" with the smart phone, and measure user's interactions with those devices, specifically, movement dynamics associated with different body parts, and neuro-physiological patterns. The project is studying how the use of such multi-faceted cues can yield a smart phone authentication system that is robust against accidental errors as well as deliberate spoofing attacks.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

This project lead to major scientific discoveries and broader impacts on the society. Details follow.

For example, (1) we discovered foundational principles that affect authentication using wearable devices; (2) found new relations in features of biometric modalities, (3) discovered vulnerabilities from new forms of attack with a view to make secure systems. These discoveries will impact the future design and development spoof-resistant authentication based on wearable devices. And, (4) we found novel authentication modalities such as authentication that use accelerometer readings from phone while tapping specific parts of the body in a user chosen sequence and can be used by visually impaired people to authenticate on the phone; hand motion based authentication; authenticating handwriting using wrist movement; and ear echo based authentication.

We found scientific rationale for some interesting observations. Our findings that keystrokes on a small form-factor mobile device is more accurate than on a desktop, even though non-intuitive because a mobile phone presents a smaller for factor, will greatly influence the design of authentication systems for seamless transition of use between mobile devices and desktop (the reason of high differentiation among users on mobile device is because of more degrees of freedom while using phone, such as hand and wrist position, angle of elbow, which are unique to a user resulting in high discrimination among users where as a desktop keyboard is typically stationed at a fixed location thus does not have much discriminant features). We have shared these findings through multiple publications and presentations in top-tier computer science journals and conferences. These findings impact not only the science of authentication but also psychology, neurosciences, biomedical engineering among others.

At Syracuse University, we have collected two large data sets to study authentication on wearable and desktop devices. We are in the process of making these data sets publicly available. The two data sets are: (1)  from 117 users in phase 1 (April –June 2017) and (2) from 104 users in phase 2 (August –October 2018) collected in collaboration with a DARPA project. In phase 1 the subjects provided data for typing (both fixed and free text), gait (walking, upstairs and downstairs) and touch on Desktop, Tablet and Phone. In phase 2 the subjects provided data using short UNIX commands to breach the security by using and adversarial activities to simulate script kiddie attacks. We are in the process of sharing analysis of this data through conference and journal publications and presentations.

In addition to the broader impacts towards developing the science of authentication, the project has impacted multiple middle school, high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. The project has trained high school teachers as well. Under the direction of PI Vir Phoha and Ms. Tamara Hamilton, Director, LSAMP, Syracuse University and through partnership between the Syracuse City School District and the NSF-funded Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP), we organized a one week intensive workshop from July 23, 2017 through July 28, 2017 for 20 middle school and 27 high school students from Syracuse City School District. (Details are: 20 participants from Middle School (14 from grade 8th and 6 from grade 7th) and 27 participants from High School (13 from 9th grade, 6 from 10th grade, 5 from 11th grade, and 3 from 12th grade. The schools represented were: Clary; Elms; Grant; HW Smith; Roberts; Salem Hyde; Wheeler; Nottingham, ITC, Corcoran. Two coordinators from Syracuse City School District selected the students.)

In addition, we have trained multiple undergraduate and graduate students through this NSF supported project including three undergraduate students trained through the NSF REU program.
